Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Story:
I was sitting at the kitchen table, surrounded by the familiar smells of my family’s holiday cooking, when my phone buzzed. My mother was telling me, once again, how important it was to keep our family traditions alive—how every year, we all had to be present, help with the preparations, and share stories from our heritage. I nodded, feeling the weight of her expectations, knowing how much it meant to her that I participate fully and respect our customs.

At that moment, I glanced at my phone and saw a message from an acquaintance I’d met at work. She was new in town and asked if I could recommend a good restaurant nearby. I knew she didn’t have many friends here yet, and she’d probably appreciate a quick reply, maybe even an offer to join her. I felt torn—my family expected my undivided attention, but I also didn’t want to let down someone who was reaching out for help. My mind raced, caught between honoring my family’s wishes and being the supportive acquaintance I wanted to be.
